notesStmt.note: Defective at the end. Stained. Folio 252 partly mutilated.

Folio 1 (a late paper flyleaf) contains an index of seliḥot for Yom Kipur. Yitsḥaḳ ben Eli῾ezer ha-Kohen: inscribed (folio 309v). Matatyah ben Yuda: inscribed (folio 309v); his name (Mataty' b"r Yudah Levi z"l) tooled on the contemporary 14th century binding.
Manuscript description based on Margoliouth, G.: Catalogue of the Hebrew and Samaritan Manuscripts in the British Museum, London 1965.

msContents.summary: A festival prayer book with services for Rosh ha-Shanah, Yom Kipur and Sukot, according to the German rite.

msItem.title: Services for the first day of Rosh ha-Shanah
Services for the second day of Rosh ha-Shanah

collation.p: Quires of mostly 8 leaves each. Catchwords at the end of the quires, mostly cut away.

scriptDesc.scriptNote: Ashkenazi square script, punctuated, of the 13th to early 14th century.

binding.p: Pre-1600. Black leather, blind-tooled, with copper centerpiece, cornerpieces and remains of clasps. Boxed. Spine: 'Mahazor. German Rite. Hebrew. Brit. Mus. Harley 5701.'

history.provenance: Acquisition: The Harley Collection, formed by Robert Harley (b. 1661, d. 1724), 1st earl of Oxford and Mortimer, politician, and Edward Harley (b. 1689, d. 1741), 2nd earl of Oxford and Mortimer, book collector and patron of the arts[, inscribed as usual by their librarian, Humfrey Wanley, ‘15 Augusti 1715’ (folio 2r). Edward Harley bequeathed the library to his widow, Henrietta Cavendish, née Holles (b. 1694, d. 1755) during her lifetime and thereafter to their daughter, Margaret Cavendish Bentinck (b. 1715, d. 1785), duchess of Portland; the manuscripts were sold by the Countess and the Duchess in 1753 to the nation for £10,000 (a fraction of their contemporary value) under the Act of Parliament that also established the British Museum; the Harley manuscripts form one of the foundation collections of the British Library.
